formattedAddress: 227 W 145th St, New York, NY 10039, USA
adrFormatAddress: 227 W 145th St, New York, NY 10039, USA

originalText.text: This the second time i came. They always deliver great cleaning service and repair. The first time i went with black thigh high boots. The guy fixed the heel and polished it. Then my sister got my uggs soaked in rain and they made them look brand new

text.text: This the second time i came. They always deliver great cleaning service and repair. The first time i went with black thigh high boots. The guy fixed the heel and polished it. Then my sister got my uggs soaked in rain and they made them look brand new

originalText.text:
This is the kind of shoe shop that you want in every neighborhood. I've been going to the since their original shop on Lenox and 129th. It was by a fluke that I even found the new location but they are just as kind and professional as they were before if not better.
Prices are reasonable, the work is good, and the turn around is relatively fast. I highly recommend them dor heal repair. And don't forget to add some taps, which are still one of the most affordable in the city.

text.text:

originalText.text: Good work. Fair prices. Professional service.

text.text: Good work. Fair prices. Professional service.

originalText.text:
I recommend this place for very simple things like adding the usual layer of rubber under a boot to correct a worn sole, maybe.

I had been dealing with the owner of Taveras for many years to fix the bottom of my shoes, fix scuffs and so on. But recently I went all the way up to 145th Street because we don't have many skilled cobblers in Harlem anymore.

When I showed the young man (Taveras' son) the split in the sole of one of my boots he abruptly and quite rudely, without even looking, said "no." I'm writing this review because this is not the first time I remember dealing with the rude, no talent having son of the owner.

This is not a time to pissing long term clients off. In case you haven't noticed, businesses are closing all over the city. The least you can do is show some respect and appreciation for the people who stop in and spend money that keeps your business open.

I will never go back to this ghetto shoe repair shop. My boots are over $600 and I plan to keep them for as long as possible. I found a real cobbler at 125 Sullivan St in the village. Their factory of talented cobblers and shoe repairmen who can literally rebuild an entire shoe if that's what you need - because they are so talented - is on 28th Street between 7th and 8th Avenues. Vince's Village Cobbler. It's more productive to take some extra time to go the distance to access real talent and respect.

originalText.text: I live in the Bronx and make my way across the bridge for my shoes all the time. They even fixed a Louis Vuitton purse that ripped recently. They are comprable with pricing, though make sure to check your bill every time. Should be standard practice everywhere you go. ðŸ˜‰
